respondent.name: No. 07-984 SOUTHEAST ALASKA CONSERVATION COUNCIL, ET AL.;

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We will hear argument first this morning in Case 07-984, Coeur Alaska v. The Southeast Alaska Conservation Council, and Case 07-990, Alaska v. The Southeast Alaska Conservation Council. General Garre.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: If the discharge comes from a single pipe, is it always one or the other, or can it ever be both fill and - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That's a legal answer to Justice Kennedy's question. What is the physical answer? Can a pipe both emit sludge, fill, and effluent?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Fill material trumps effluent, in other words?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But it does -- here's the problem that I am having and I think others may have. We start, number one, with a definition, as I understand it, of a pollutant that includes suspended solids. Number two, there is an existing regulation to the effect that wastewater from this particular method of extracting gold shall simply not be released, shall not be put into a water body. And then the two agencies come along and in effect they say by regulation, if the suspended solid in effect comes out of a mine, or if the wastewater has got suspended solid in it, we are going to call it "fill" and leave it entirely to the Army Engineers under 404, subject to an EPA veto. And on the face of it, it sounds as though they are simply, number one, defining one -- one variant of pollution out of the EPA's jurisdiction, and, number two, with respect to the wastewater, in effect coming up with a contradictory determination about what should be done with it. And it sounds as though, under the Administrative Procedure Act, that with the statutory and the regulatory regime on the one hand and this joint regulation on the other, you've simply got a flat contradiction, and query whether that can be anything other than arbitrary and capricious under the APA. Will you address that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, let's assume -- and I don't mean to cut you off there, but before you're done -- I am at least raising it because I find it very difficult to get a handle on this case without dealing with that problem. So you may say, well, they didn't raise it well enough, but I still want you to deal with it on the merits.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How could it be settled, because isn't it a fact that before 2002 if the primary purpose was disposing of waste that the 402 permit applied?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So it's not in 30 years' experience, and when it was disposing of waste, it was under 402 until 2002.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But in fact, was there ever a permit by the Corps of Engineers when the purpose was disposal of waste? Was there ever a 404 permit, rather than a 402, for disposal of what they call "processed wastewater" or "wastewater"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: That's pretty cold comfort when you treat as an impoundment area a natural lake. I suppose if the -- if it's proper to do what they're doing here, then the lake in the middle of the Everglades is an impoundment area, or a Great Salt Lake is an impoundment area.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: This is a long way from a settling pond.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes, but what's that - - what's that got to do with the definition of "impoundment area"? My problem is that you are treating -- the Corps is treating as an impoundment area a whole natural lake as distinct from a settling basin.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: You keep saying they are rigorous. My understanding is -- and I didn't think it was seriously disputed here -- is that during the period in which the deposits are going to be made, the natural life of this water body is going to be destroyed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And the Corps comes along and says, oh, when it's all over, it will come back. But when you're destroying the entire living sort of corpus of this lake, it seems to me that it's getting more lenient to say that there are rigorous environmental standards.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, but as I understand it, and you correct me if I am wrong here, I thought "suspended solids," I guess is the buzz word for it, is a form of pollution. So you're saying, well, we're destroying the fish with one form of pollution rather than another form of pollution. And I don't know that that advances the ball for your side.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes, but this comes back to my initial question. You are simply, or the Corps is simply, defining what would otherwise be a pollutant, suspended solids discharged into the water, by calling it fill material. And it -- in effect it's defining one subject of -- of discharge regulation right out of the law of the United States by redefining it and saying, oh, it doesn't exist if it's coming out of a mine.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But to apply the effects test, the legal effect, is it not, is to define one form of pollution as no longer existent so long as that form of pollution falls within the Corps of Engineers definition of "fill."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Is that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: General Garre, I don't want to take up your rebuttal time, but what's the environmental alternative to what was done here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Weren't they then thinking of fill material as material that was used either to fill in, to reclaim land, or in a construction project? I mean, to call filling a lake, to call that a fill, when what it's doing is providing a disposal place for a mining operation, it's not what one ordinarily thinks of as a filling operation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There's one question that Justice Souter raised and before you sit down I would like to get your answer, and that is, can anything, any water of the United States that the Corps of Engineers decides is appropriate to be used as a disposal place, can any waterway be a settling pond? That is, here we have a lake. And is it just up to the Corps of Engineers? They say this is a settling pond, it's a settling pond?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, General.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Olson.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But doesn't the EPA have a veto power over the fill material permit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So they're not totally mutually exclusive.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Could they veto it due to its failure to comply with effluent limitations?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What happens if the agencies disagree as to whether it's fill? If 404 says it's fill, EPA says it isn't, can the EPA then veto it on that ground?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But there are still going to be cases, I would assume very close cases, even under the present standard, where there could be disagreement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The definition that was adopted, if I have it right, was the EPA definition. That was the effect. And it was the Corps that had the purpose test. And yet, until 2002, if I understand correctly, if the only reason of raising the elevation of the lake was to dispose of waste, you didn't get a 404 permit. That was not a 404 situation until 2002.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But in an application that never included filling a lake, raising the elevation of a lake simply for the purpose of disposing of waste.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I -- I perhaps am missing this. I -- this is in general what I don't understand, how this works. My understanding is that under 404 something is "fill" -- they have a definition. And it's "fill," among other things, if it changes the bottom level of any portion of water in the United States. Is that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And somewhere I have the idea -- but I can't find it in the briefs now -- that it has to raise the bottom level by 55 feet.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: There is some number of feet.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's the result of this case. But, anyway, it raises the level. I guess it has to raise it some significant amount. All right. So what happens in this situation? Let us think of the worst pollutant you can think of. Think of that. I don't know what it is. Maybe it's saturated fat in potato chips, something absolutely terrible.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. We are going to think of that pollutant. And now let's suppose that with the agreement of the Army Corps of Engineers a company takes this pollutant, which is the worst one you could think of, that the EPA would never let you go within 50 feet of it, and they take it, and they fill a lake with it up to the level of 55 feet, or 20 feet, or whatever number of feet. I mean, it just can't be that simply because they poured a lot of it in and it fills up the bottom of the lake that suddenly the EPA can't regulate it any more. Now, that -- that -- since that's so counterintuitive, that all you have to do is take a terrible pollutant and fill the bottom of the lake with it and now it's up to the Army Corps of Engineers and not up to the EPA -- that's so counterintuitive that I assume I don't understand the statute, and you will explain it to me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Uh-huh.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But it can contain it so long as it is -- as it -- as it is not transitory.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, isn't it arguable that the best place for -- for really toxic stuff is at the bottom of a lake so long as it stays there and is not carried - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It is identical. So it doesn't make any difference.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I -- I heard you say before that it was not identical. That -- I mean if, of course, EPA takes all its regs and applies those regs when the Army Corps of Engineers considers a permit under 404 so that you couldn't get an Army Corps of Engineers permit unless you complied with the 402 etcetera regs, then this all could come to nothing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So there must be something missing in that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What is the most important thing that is missing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I think what might be missing - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is nontoxic covered by 402?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Nontoxic is covered by 402. You -- you can violate the effluent guidelines by -- by pouring into the waters of the United States even nontoxic materials, isn't that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And under 404 it'S only toxic.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And that's the big difference.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But it's going to kill every living creature in the lake, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Wait a minute. It is going to kill everything in the lake.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And how do we know that life will ever be restored? I mean, that's a guess. Nobody knows.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Olson. Mr. Waldo.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Of course, the provision that authorizes permits begins by saying "Except as provided in sections 1328 and 1344," and 1344 is 404. So why doesn't that just take the 404 regime completely out of what you were just talking about?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: The standard has to be - - the standard has to be applicable and this is an EPA regulation, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And the EPA has said this isn't applicable to this situation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So your position requires us to determine that EPA's interpretation of those, the statutory regime that you are talking about, 306 and 402, is contrary to the statute?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If EPA were to amend the performance standard to say that it doesn't apply in the situation in which the fill rule applies, would that be a valid regulation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Could the -- could the EPA allow a point source to discharge sand slurry -- there's nothing in it but sand -- into a river? Wouldn't you have to -- wouldn't you need some permission from the EPA to do that? Wouldn't that violate the Act?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I want to discharge. I have a pipe and there is sand on my land which is being washed away. I'm discharging all that sand into a river.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Would that violate - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Discharge of a pollutant.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Now, if I do the same thing in a lake, because I want to fill the lake, of what possible application is the fill standard unless it permits what would otherwise be prohibited under - - under the earlier sections?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Even though it violates effluent standards.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But you say -- you say that if you discharge sand into -- into a river it violates effluent standards.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The discharges we are talking about have to be discharges of effluent, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: My question is, does it apply to solids?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I guess, I mean, does suspended solids mean there is some liquid involved?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Like the discharge here. Now, I think Mr. Olson said these are 55 percent solid by volume.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Is there a point at which it's proper to speak of it as a solid rather than a suspended solid? I mean, 90 percent by weight or by volume, whichever it is, solid?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You wouldn't think something that's 90 percent solid is wastewater?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So if they were just putting whatever it is that doesn't have any water, concrete, into this lake, then you agree that it would be just the Corps of Engineers through the fill -- fill provisions that would govern that?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And so, if they chop up the concrete and put a little water in so that it's easier to move, then all of a sudden it comes under 402 and the EPA's jurisdiction?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I guess I'm just curious how that makes any sense, since we are talking about putting something into water. I mean, does it really matter whether you add the water before it goes into the lake or just the lake adds the water when you put in the solid?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERT
speakers.text: Either way, I guess your friends on the other side would argue, I assume, that it's properly regarded as fill material, because that is the effect of it, rather than as effluent subject to 402.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So do we decide -- we decide this case on the assumption that this is fill? Do you agree that this is fill?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, then the question that we've put earlier is whether or not a single pipe contained both, and you say that it can contain both.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It's one -- visibly, it's one stream, but you say it consists of two things.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is it both slurry -- is it both fill and non-fill?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, if it's both -- do you agree that there can be only one permit; there can't be a 402 and a 404 permit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: All right. So, let's change that. What if the -- what if the new source performance standard was not a total prohibition? What if there was an effluent limitation in there, so that a permit could be issued, provided that there was compliance with the effluent limitation? Now, who issues the permit? And I repeat, I understand it's your position that there can't be both a 402 and a 404 permit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Where do you find that in the statute?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Where there's a situation where possibly there could be a 402 and a 404 permit, the 402 permit trumps the 404 permit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: This wouldn't be an operation in violation of a performance standard. There would be a performance standard.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: That can be put into a 402 permit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And 402 doesn't make any application for -- for the 404 regulations.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Where does it make the - - where does it make provision for application of the standards that should apply to fill under 404?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Where does the statute say that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Where does it say that? You say that there can't be two permits and you say 402 trumps 404. And I'm asking where in the statute does it say that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Could you go - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Excuse me. Could you go back for a second to my discussion with Mr. Olson? I'm thinking of it in very simplified terms. The simplified terms is, I think of a pipe and I think of a circumstance where some terrible pollutant comes out of the pipe that would be subject to 306; and if the pipe goes up in a river or a lake, a regular lake, it could fill up the bottom. Seems possible.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. So if it fills up the bottom, it's called fill and comes under 404.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, I know, I know that. I see the point. But I mean, it seems to me if it fills up to the bottom to whatever point, it's fill, and now it's the Army Corps of Engineers. If it has effluent in it, it's effluent and so now it's under EPA. In other words, you have both.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's only been going on for 40 years. I'm sure this isn't the first time they've had both.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And -- and so I don't understand. What I would think of is if you have two sets of standards and it's both, they should satisfy both. I'm not writing these statutes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, I heard from -- and I might interpret Mr. Olson -- he may not have really said this, but the way I heard it was: Well, don't worry, because if it's fill and you get it over to the Corps of Engineers, they are going to apply the effluent standard anyway. And now you are sort of saying: Well, or they are going to apply some standard. And then there was a question of well, what standard, and we got a little vague there. Now, what happens if it goes to the EPA as effluent? Justice Alito's question is, well, do they apply the fill standard? And between my response to these two answers, I still don't understand how it works. It's -- help me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay. So now, if you lose this case, what we are going to have is all the fish are going to be killed by some horrible pollutant, and the -- the Army Corps of Engineers can't do anything about it, and the only reason is we put enough of the pollutant in there to fill it up to ten feet from the bottom. And then if you did it the other way, if the EPA regulated it, it might do something terrible under 404, and they couldn't do anything about it. Now it's very hard for me to believe that that's really how these agencies have been operating for 40 years.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Even when they - - even fill -- even when they fill a lake?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So when EPA regulates has regulated these for 40 years, which I assume is up until 2002, then it's -- it's because they don't go into lakes; it's because they go into settling ponds?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Which are not navigable waters of the United States.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So the new regulation says the EPA does not regulate it when it goes into -- I can understand why the Army Corps of Engineers doesn't care if it's an impoundment pond or a settling pond, but they do care when it's a lake.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: To fill material as defined in the 2002 regulation?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Which, which, which -- I'm sorry, which Fill Rule?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes. You are talking about the preamble. I'm looking at the definition of fill material in -- whatever -- it's reproduced at page 7a and 8a of the government's brief.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The -- definition - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, but -- but do you have a -- a case over these 40 years where a company was trying to use the emission from the mine as a fill material in a lake rather than in a settling pond, and where the EPA, despite the fact that it was using it to fill a lake, applied its effluent standards?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, then - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Evidently not. I mean, the EPA says not. Do you have a -- an instance where it was prohibited where a company wanted to -- to emit fill material into a lake and the EPA said no, you can't do it, because of the effluent limitations?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But your -- your 40 years of experience then really don't -- don't cover this case. People have been putting it into settling ponds. Let me ask you another question. The other side says that the alternative to this would be even worse, or it sounds worse to me, anyway. What -- what is your solution, closing down the mine? Is there - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- your description of that effect? The other solution we were told would involve filling in a vast expanse of wetlands and then having these huge piles that could be seen by all the tourist boats.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: All the fish, there are a thousand fish in this lake, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And those aren't endangered fish; there are millions of them somewhere else, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Wasn't there a decision in the lower courts that the alternative was unacceptable as well? And would you represent that if the case were remanded, that would not be your position on remand?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: It was never your position that that was unacceptable?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: It was never your client's position that creating these permanently destroyed wetlands and creating a mound that was bigger than the Pentagon was an unacceptable solution to the - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why do you said the EPA preferred the -- the solution of filling in the wetlands and creating an ash Pentagon?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, if it really felt that way, couldn't it simply have vetoed the permit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So it couldn't have felt very strongly about it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It couldn't have preferred it very much, or it would have vetoed this one.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Is there any aquatic life in this lake other than a thousand fish?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Microinvertebrae?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Plankton and stuff.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is it right - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is it right -- now, I am back on my hobby horse -- but is it right that this slurry is pushing into this lake 50 feet or 75 feet covering the bottom with some stuff? A lot of it's dirt, and some of it's the worst chemical ever, except it's not toxic? Okay. I guess cyanide isn't toxic. But the -- the -- now I just heard that if the EPA doesn't give the permit, but the Corps of Engineers does, the EPA has the power to veto the permit. Is that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why not? If they have a veto power - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I know it comes under a different statute, but in any instance where in fact they see that some of their rules that they promulgate are being violated and they think the Corps of Engineers is not paying attention to those rules, they can veto it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If they don't veto it, then that would be a way of reconciling these two things.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So couldn't they veto it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And wouldn't an unacceptable adverse consequence be that it puts all this effluent into the water?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Isn't that the pH at the point where it's discharged, and not the general pH in the lake?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What's the answer to the question, when -- once it's released into the lake, what's the pH of the lake as opposed to the - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Within how long?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: The pH that you just cited was the pH - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: -- just at the point of the discharge?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Just to follow up, that's the same point, though, that Justice Alito made: You're testing that right as it comes out, not as it's diluted in the lake.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry, I didn't understand you. I thought you said that the toxicity in the slurry was tested and killed 99 or whatever percent of these invertebrates.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If, in fact, you have this mix, and it satisfies -- it goes to an effluent part and a fill part, in your view, what -- if the statute says both agencies regulate, they have to meet both, one or the other? How does it work?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You say this is 404; it's not 402 - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It is 306?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But it is fill.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So fill material is only that material as to which no effluent standard applies?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: 404 material is material such that it is fill material and there is no effluent standard applicable?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So, it's 95 percent solid, but there's an effluent limitation, and your position is that there can't be a 404 permit; it has to be a 402 permit?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Go ahead. Finish your thought.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Waldo.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Olson, you have three minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But I thought -- I thought your brother would say: But that does not respond to 306 effluent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Why does that mean anything more than you've got to get a 404 permit without addressing the question whether you can get a 404 permit if it has, in effect, the -- the -- if it has the effects which are supposed to be regulated by the effluent limitations?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Where is -- where is that in the appendix?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But as I read that sentence, Mr. Olson, it says they are subject to both permitting.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: You are talking about the last sentence on - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Olson. The case is submitted.
